title: Renaissance Iconography
description: In their study of Renaissance Italy, students become experts on the narratives and iconography of 15 paintings of the period. They create a presentation of their findings to share with their peers. They also explore some of the major commissions of the period, such as the renovation of St. Peter’s Basilica. This project also ties into their study of Machiavelli’s The Prince in English, during which they play a Renaissance simulation game based on the text. In the game, the paintings studied become “cultural items” that can be acquired during auction. During Visual Arts, students sketch the body using Renaissance techniques. In Science, they study the work of Leonardo as a scientist and artist. Their work from this project is captured in their Leonardo Sketchbook as a summative assessment for Science and Visual Arts.
caption: The Birth of Venus, c.1485 (tempera on canvas), Botticelli, Sandro (1444/5-1510) / Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence, Italy / Bridgeman Images

title: Earth Systems Animation
description: For the final integrated project of the Earth Systems unit, students create a film presentation that challenges them to organize and synthesize the knowledge that they have gleaned during their interdisciplinary study of Earth systems.
caption: © Ron Blakey Colorado Plateau Geosystems Inc.

title: Renaissance Simulation Game
description: The Renaissance Simulation Game is designed to reinforce the concepts contained in Machiavelli’s The Prince by having students compete with one another as princes during the Italian Renaissance.

title: Introduction to Systems Using the Soroban
description: In this four-week project, students use and evaluate a calculation system using an ancient tool: the soroban, or Japanese abacus. In the process, they reinforce their understanding of place-value concepts and the associative property, learn a new mental-math strategy (Anzan) based on visualizing numbers modeled on the soroban, and continue to develop their computational fluency with sums less than 20 and their fact families.

title: Earth Systems: Water and Land on Earth
description: Students discover the meaning of percentages and fractions of a whole as they interpret and model given percentages for the amounts of land, water, and types of water on Earth. They then use a whole square with fewer than 100 equal parts, while keeping the part-to-whole ratios of water and land the same, to model equivalent fractions.

title: How to Measure Temperature on Earth
description: In integration with Cultural History and Science, students investigate the temperatures of precipitation, discovering the melting and freezing temperatures of water in both Fahrenheit and Celsius. Students compare different scales for temperature, including benchmark temperatures for qualitative descriptions. They recognize the importance of using standard units of measurement as they make a class graph to record temperature data collected.

title: Solar System Studies
description: Students focus on the attributes of planet Earth, exploring how it is both similar to and different from other planets in the Solar System. Students build a model of Earth and its atmosphere, showing the unique qualities that make it a hospitable planet. Students then make a diagram of the atmosphere, describing the layers that provide the oxygen and thermoregulation necessary for life on Earth.

title: Local Ecosystem Terrarium
description: This integrated project provides an opportunity for students to visit and explore a local forest ecosystem and construct a model in the form of a terrarium. As a result, students have the opportunity to observe two different ecosystems in action in the classroom on a daily basis and to compare the systems.

title: The Renaissance Dissection Project
description: Students explore how the science and art of dissection were revolutionized during the Renaissance. Students perform dissections on one of three vertebrates (frog, rat, or fetal pig). This project has several components: dissection, recording of dissection through several forms of media, sketching of the viscera and an organ system, online research of organs, combining information into a virtual notebook (a collection of slides), and giving an oral presentation to accompany the slideshow. The students’ sketches also are annotated and submitted as part of their Leonardo Sketchbooks in their Visual Arts class.

title: Commedia dell’Arte
description: Experimenting with actual scenarios used by commediatroops that toured Europe during the Renaissance, students learn about stock characters and the art of slapstick.

title: The Myth of Faust Puppet Theater Presentations
description: The Faust myth reflects the tension between human desire for worldly advancement and long-standing religiousï»¿ authority. In this integrated project, students present a progression of the myth in a puppet theater format.

title: Visionary Leaders Trial Project
description: Students work in groups to stage a mock trial to prosecute a visionary leader. They offer differing viewpoints based on the perspectives of the colonizer and the colonized.

title: The Modernity Project
description: Students culminate their studies in this unit with the Modernity Project, an interdisciplinary assignment that addresses the essential question “What is modernity?”

title: Media Activism Project and Research Paper
description: Students choose a subject for an individual media project that takes a position on a topic of global significance, preferably one connected with their initial thesis statement at the end of the Self-Determination and the Excesses of Nationalism unit, and write a first draft of their formal research paper.

title: Visionary Leaders Trial Project
description: Students work in teams of five or six to do historical research and compose, stage, and perform a 10- to 15-minute play in which a revolutionary figure of the late 19th or early 20th century is prosecuted and defended for his or her actions. The “trial” setting requires students to explore and ultimately present both sides of the story surrounding their historical figure’s actions.

title: English Constitutionalism, John Locke, and Robinson Crusoe
description: After examining the work of Locke and Hobbes, students synthesize these concepts with their reading of Robinson Crusoe by Daniel Defoe. The following guiding question helps frame students’ thinking: “How does the Protestant concept of the self affect both economics and literature?”

title: Understanding the Yoruba
description: Students learn about the rich culture and advanced society of the Yoruba people of West Africa. They conduct interdisciplinary research and share their findings to deepen their understanding of the Yoruba.

title: Understanding the Haudenosaunee
description: Students learn about the Haudenosaunee culture and the influence of the Haudenosaunee Confederacy on the U.S. Constitution.

title: Complex Dynamical System: The Great Irish Potato Famine
description: A systems analysis study of an Gorta Mór, the Great Irish Potato Famine, provides a counterpoint to the supposed achievements of the Great Exhibition. Students use a NetLogo model to explore how land division affected the availability of food to the population of Ireland and to study the effects of fungus on Ireland’s potato crop. Finally, students investigate how both the declining potato crop and emigration affected the population of Ireland.

title: Rice-and-Stocking Babies Project
description: Students use rice and stockings to create babies in their own likenesses, using their own height and weight at the time of their birth. Through shared storytelling, research, and observation, they learn what is needed to take care of their babies.

title: English Constitutionalism, John Locke, and Robinson Crusoe
description: Students synthesize their learning from their English and Cultural History classes to write an essay about Locke’s influence on the Glorious Revolution and Robinson Crusoe.

title: Calculating Elapsed Time: Timelines Throughout Our Evolving Planet
description: Students integrate Cultural History, Science, and Visual Arts to create four timelines and calculate elapsed time. They relate the scale and divisions of geological time to more familiar time periods and linear measures. For each timeline, students determine and use appropriate units of time (for the number scale) and length, to scale the timeline to different physical dimensions and represent intervals of elapsed time proportionately.

title: How Big Is Your Brain?
description: Students explore increasing brain size as they continue their exploration of human evolution, using centimeter cubes to model the volume of the brains of hominid species.

title: Iroquois Wampum
description: Students integrate Cultural History, World Languages and Literature: English, and Visual Arts to further explore the concepts of Iroquois trade and currency. Students examine practices and logistics of bartering and create clay wampum in three denominations for use in a simulated marketplace at the end of the unit.

title: A Mathematical Investigation of Golden Greek Art and Architecture
description: In this two-week project, students consider how mathematics influenced ancient and classical Greek definitions of natural beauty and balance. Using proportions and other mathematical relationships, students investigate the possible connections between the Golden Ratio, the human body, and Greek statues, structures, and buildings, including the Doryphorus, the Parthenon, and the Apollo Temple in Didyma. Students then learn how two-dimensional nets can represent three-dimensional objects. They use their new knowledge and their understanding of ratio and proportion to create scale models of selected golden structures.

title: A Mathematical Journey via the Silk Road
description: Students investigate the economics of the Silk Road—the production, distribution, consumption, and management of goods and services—and relate it to their studies of Silk Road cultural exchanges and geography in both Cultural History and Science. They pose as merchants, take an imaginary trading journey along the Silk Road between Southern Europe and China, determine the distances between stops, and express the value and profitability of their trades. Students blog about their experiences.

title: Dwellings: Early Human Settlements
description: Students begin to examine the environment from two perspectives: places that offer shelter from the elements, and places that offer resources for the construction of dwellings. Students visit a local nature preserve to explore the habitat as a shelter-seeker and then build small models of human dwellings using natural materials.

title: The Guild Project
description: In this culminating hands-on project, students synthesize their learning to simulate the experience of working in a medieval guild.

title: Energy in the Modern World
description: After an overview of types of energy used in the modern period, students discuss the pitfalls of these energy sources and explore alternative sources in small groups, analyzing the sources for efficacy and sustainability, and presenting the groups’ findings to their classmates. The presentation may involve various types of media components.

title: Recycling Paper
description: Students experience recycling firsthand by collecting used paper and making new paper from the old. This project connects students to the Patterns in Living Things unit, as they learn that paper comes from trees and that if paper is recycled, fewer trees have to be cut down.

title: Dinosaur Tree Journals
description: Students listen to a read-aloud of Dinosaur Tree by Douglas Henderson. Using note-taking and other skills learned in Writing Workshop, students retell the story as a journal entry written from the first-person perspective of the dinosaur tree.

title: Dinosaur Study
description: In an integrated World Languages and Literature: English, Cultural History, Science, Visual Arts, and Media Studies and Technology project, students research a specific dinosaur species and create multiple pieces of a presentation that will be shared with the community at the Evolving Planet Museum.

title: Mammals and Scale
description: Students draw the prehistoric mammals they have researched using a predetermined scale, which allows them to compare and contrast sizes of different animals. This project integrates Cultural History, Mathematics, Science, and Visual Arts.

title: Archaeoastronomy Moon Symposium: Making Sense of Time Using the Sun, Moon, and Stars—Moon Journals and Calendar Tools
description: For the final summative assessment of the Neolithic Social Systems and Cultural Practices unit, students create a calendar tool and Moon Journal to organize and synthesize the knowledge that they have gleaned during their interdisciplinary study of Neolithic cultural practices.

title: Archaeological Dig Simulation
description: Students are challenged to apply their knowledge from their Cultural History, Mathematics, and Visual Arts studies in a simulated archaeological dig. They examine the specimens they find and interpret their significance as cultural artifacts. Students carry out the simulated dig by working in small, collaborative groups as teams of archaeologists.

title: The Human Settlement Project
description: In this integrated project, which serves as a summative assessment, students work as teams of archaeologists that have been studying and researching the Neolithic Agricultural Revolution. A fictional History Channel is having a contest to fund a full-length documentary based on one team’s research of a Neolithic settlement.

title: Literature of Ancient Sumer: Hymn to Inanna
description: In a project that spans the domains of Visual Arts, English, Mathematics, and Science, students explore the myth and hymns of Inanna, the favorite goddess of the Sumerians. They write and illustrate a book titled The Book of Inanna to demonstrate what they learn.

title: Ancient Sumer Brochure
description: Students design and create tourist brochures for ancient Sumer by synthesizing historical facts and using their imagination.

title: Characteristics of Civilization: Ancient Sumer
description: Students complete the Characteristics of Civilization Table for Sumer and decorate each table with hand-drawn illustrations.

title: Ancient Egypt
description: Students research topics pertaining to ancient Egypt, such as animals, agriculture, artifacts, river life, or clothing, and present multimedia shows based on what they learn. Creative visual pieces the students have been researching act as backdrops on projected screens while students perform. These capstone projects create an authentic ambience for integrated learning about the ancient Egyptians.

title: Characteristics of Civilization: Ancient Egypt
description: Students fill out the Characteristics of Civilization Chart for Egypt, in which they identify the five characteristics of civilization in each of the six ancient civilizations studied in this course. This is an ongoing project throughout the year; once each chart is complete, it is kept in a separate folder for reference.

title: Hindu Deities Project
description: To gain a deeper understanding of the polytheistic nature of Hinduism, each student engages in a research project about a selected Hindu deity. This project consists of five components: research, essay, illustration, costume, and performance.

title: Ancient China and the Banpo Village Research Project
description: Through a study of the Shang Dynasty and the Banpo Village archaeology site, students investigate the shift from a matristic society to patriarchal civilization in ancient China. Students are introduced to the geography of the region prior to their research project.

title: Characteristics of Civilization: Indus Valley, Ancient China, and Peru’s Caral-Supe Valley
description: Students complete a Characteristics of Civilization Chart for the regions of ancient China and the Banpo Village studied in this unit.

title: Characteristics of Civilization: Minoan Crete
description: As part of the yearlong Characteristics of Civilization project, students identify examples of the five characteristics of civilization in Minoan Crete, completing and illustrating a chart for their portfolio.

title: Class Civilization
description: The yearlong, major integrated civilization project comes together as students work in small groups to prepare a multimedia fifth-grade curriculum summary presentation. As a culminating project, students work in small groups to contribute to the ongoing fifth-grade project: designing an imaginary class civilization and making formal presentations to other classes.

title: Empty Bowls Project
description: Working within the framework of the Empty Bowls Project, a grassroots effort to help end world hunger, students raise awareness of hunger as an issue locally, nationally, and internationally in this integrated project.

title: American Revolution Pamphlet Project
description: Students choose a propagandist from the era of the American Revolution to research, learning about the propagandist's life and the issues the person passionately championed. Taking the role of the propagandist, students write a pamphlet with illustrations. They then write a reflection on the project.

title: Olmec Were-Creature Project
description: In this Were-Creature Project, students explore the shape-shifting qualities of the Olmec shaman by reading an excerpt about shape-shifting from the novel Blood and Chocolate by Annette Curtis Klause, choosing an animal to morph into, using digital technology to demonstrate the morphing, and writing and recording a voice-over script.

title: The Biblical Times Project
description: Using topics researched in the Ancient Hebrews Group Project, students create a website home page or a page from a newspaper titled The Biblical Times.

title: Greek Week
description: The unit culminates in Greek Week, in which students give oral reports, perform Greek tragedies, participate in a Math Olympiad, compete in a historical Jeopardy! game, play sports, and prepare a Greek banquet.

title: The U.S. Civil War Movie Project
description: Students work in pairs to create five-minute movies on a Civil War topic. The assignment includes creating a storyboard, writing the script, searching for and acknowledging images from both print and Internet sources, creating voice-over narration and music, and using techniques like those of Ken Burns in the final product.

title: Seasonal Changes: Migration–Time and Measurement
description: This integrated project corresponds with students’ multisensory activities in Cultural History, Visual Arts, and Science. Students continue to investigate seasonal changes and their effects on living things by correlating studies from other domains and recording discussions, observations, and findings in their Mathematics Journals. Students correlate seasonal patterns specific to animal behaviors due to weather and climate changes to the measurement of time on a calendar.

title: The Malthus Project: Playing with Historical Data
description: Students review historical data from the late 19th century and explore the impact that industrialization had on various sectors of life in Great Britain. Their exploration leads them to the data underlying Malthus’s hypotheses about the human predicament (exponential growth in human population will outrun the arithmetic growth of food supplies). This project is introduced and jointly taught by both the Mathematics and Science instructors and reinforced by the Cultural History class. Environmental and population sciences are the lens used by the Science domain, while the Mathematics domain focuses on statistics, functions, and regression analyses.

title: Introduction to Einstein’s Relativity Theory
description: Since the theory of relativity affected the arts and the cultural discourse about the nature of reality and truth, students are introduced to the underlying concepts of Einstein’s theory of relativity. The concepts of relative motion and wave behavior are examined. Poincaré’s contributions to understanding the principle of relative motion are also discussed, in that he and Einstein arrived at similar conclusions without fully acknowledging each other’s work.

title: Dwellings Project
description: Incorporating studies in Cultural History and Science, students find and create examples of early human dwellings. As a class, they create a life-size model shelter.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: For their Performance of Understanding, grade 2 students perform their part in the dramatic movement piece Beginnings, a fully integrated performance for grades K through 6.

title: Printing and Painting on Silk Scarves
description: Students design and paint a black ink design and red ink-block print on silk scarves. The unit’s culminating activity combines students’ learning of brush painting, block printing, calligraphy, and Chinese symbols and characters.

title: Bombyx mori, Sericulture, and the Silk Road
description: Over a six-week period, students raise their own silkworms to observe the life cycle and effects of domestication on Bombyx mori,, and they enrich their understanding of the history and process of sericulture by attempting to harvest raw silk themselves. This project integrates with students’ Cultural History and Mathematics studies of transcontinental trade via the Silk Road.

title: Ancient Egypt Project
description: The Egypt unit culminates with a multimedia presentation and performance. The creative visual pieces the students have been researching and presenting will serve as backdrops on projected screens. The reenactments are designed to create an authentic ambience for integrated learning about the ancient Egyptians.

title: Hindu Deities Project
description: For this integrated project, students research, write an essay on, and draw an illustration of one particular Hindu god or goddess in collaboration with their Cultural History studies.

title: The Greek Tragedies
description: In this integrated project, students perform a play after reading three Greek tragedies: Aeschylus’ Prometheus Bound, Sophocles’ Antigone, and Euripides’ Iphigenia in Aulis. They audition for roles and are cast by the Performing Arts teacher. They work with their classmates to rehearse, prepare costumes, and design backdrops. They learn elements of stagecraft, vocal and physical interpretation of a character, and memorization techniques. Students contextualize the characters and themes of each play through ongoing classwork in each domain. Additionally, students keep a journal to record the feelings and motivations of their character, as well as episodes in their play from their character’s point of view.

title: Islamic Literature: An Analysis of The Rubáiyát
description: Students learn about Omar Khayyám as a mathematician, scientist, and poet and read his Rubáiyát.. They also compose their own poetry in the style and meter of Khayyám’s work.

title: Boccaccio’s Decameron and the Plague
description: Students read the frame story of The Decameron by Giovanni Boccaccio, in which he describes how the plague hit Florence in 1348. Students read and summarize what they learn and record it on a drawing of a rat. Students then read and map assigned selections from the 100 stories of The Decameronand record their learning on a descriptive map.

title: WPA/Radio Program/Silent Movie Research Project
description: Students choose between creating artwork in the style of the WPA, writing a script for a radio program, or producing a silent film to explore and further enhance their knowledge and experience of the 1920s and 1930s. This is also a research project. In addition to their creative work, students write a two- to three-page research report on their topic, including a bibliography.

title: Sumerian Tokens to Numbers Project
description: In this weeklong project, students learn how to use the sexagesimal (base-60) number system to read and write cuneiform numbers. Students begin by reviewing their experiences with one-to-one correspondence systems, then discuss the role Sumerian clay tokens and pictograms played in the evolution of cuneiform script. Students also reflect on the contributions that this Sumerian-Babylonian number system had on our base-10 place value system. This project integrates with their study of star clocks in Science and is also supported by work in their Visual Arts class, where students design and make cuneiform clay tablets.

title: Columbus’s Mathematical Errors
description: Students participate in a lecture that analyzes the mapping of Columbus’s journey. They consider the “big circles” on a globe and recognize that the distance around Earth along the equator is greater than the distance at other latitudes. They also discuss Ptolemy’s and Eratosthenes’s calculations of the Earth’s circumference. Students discover Columbus’s error in adjusting Marinus of Tyre’s method.

title: Renaissance Perspective Project
description: Students learn about the artwork of several Renaissance painters and how they applied mathematical ideas as techniques in creating art. Students apply ratios, proportions, and what they have learned about parallel and perpendicular lines to construct a tile floor.

title: Euler and Function Notation
description: Students learn the importance and benefits of function notation. They also study its history, in particular its development by Euler and other mathematicians who were searching for clear written methods to communicate their work on problems related to Newton’s laws of motions and other scientific principles.

title: The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art
description: Students research the Chinese text The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art, as well as commentaries by Liu Hui and Li Chunfeng, and discuss its importance and its influence on Chinese mathematics. They select a problem from the text, research the methods used to solve it, then write a solution.

title: Geometry of Optics
description: Students study the behavior of light to understand the equality of angles of incidence and reflection in flat, concave, and convex mirrors. They then study the behavior of light and the angle of refraction through two transparent media. This supports the study of optics that is part of grade 10 Science.

title: Statistical Inference
description: Students participate in two discussions on the scientific method and statistical inference. The class begins with a simple discussion looking at how much evidence is required to reject a claim. How large a sample is enough? How different? Students then do a few simple z-tests. In the discussion that follows, they look at how different each cell in a two-way table must be in order to reject a hypothesis claim. A series of hypothesis tests are then conducted using a graphing calculator to perform z-tests. The lecture concludes with a Punnett square hypothesis test. This leads directly into 11th grade genetic modeling using Virtual Courseware for Inquiry-Based Science Education.

title: Ptolemy’s Table
description: Students complete a project in which they explore Ptolemy’s table of chords and its connections to the sine function.

title: Tesseract
description: Students are given a reading about uncertainty and the change in modern mathematics. As a class, they discuss what the definitions of x and x2 are visually. They then discuss complex numbers and their practical uses, followed by a discussion of Pablo Picasso and cubism and the multidimensional expression of form. A picture of a cube is presented to students, and they are asked what it is. As a class, they discuss that it is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional object, and that they are going to make a three-dimensional representation of a four-dimensional object. Students are then guided through a step-by-step construction to create a four-dimensional hypercube called a tesseract.

title: Hindu Deities Project
description: Students learn about Hindu gods and goddesses in Cultural History. In Visual Arts, students take a field trip to a Hindu temple or view photos of one. They then view excerpts from the film Sita Sings the Blues and paint “portraits” of their chosen deity. Lastly, using their portraits as a guide, they create costumes for themselves to wear when delivering their essays on their deities to the class.

title: Shirin Neshat Project
description: Students are introduced to the art of Shirin Neshat, an Iranian-born photographer whose powerful work combines Arabic calligraphy and photographic images, often of Muslim women. Students reflect upon her work and produce photographic self-portraits interpreting her style and that of Cindy Sherman in their own way.

title: The African Experience
description: In a collective experience, students explain the origins of their mud cloth designs and present an original interpretation of an African song, folktale, or poem accompanied by Udu drumming.

title: Hibernating Animals in Clay
description: As part of an integrated project with Cultural History, students create clay models of hibernating baby animals.

title: Illuminated Manuscript
description: Students use their chant composition as the basis for an original illumination, drawing on their studies in Visual Arts.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge and understanding of the four elements—air, fire, water, and Earth—through a culminating, fully integrated performance.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: For their Performance of Understanding, first grade students perform their part of the story in the dramatic movement piece Beginnings, a fully integrated performance for grades K–6.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: For their Performance of Understanding, grade 3 students perform their part of the dramatic movement piece Beginnings,

title: Wax Museum
description: To prepare for their performance in the Early Human Wax Museum integrated project, students use improvisational exercises to develop a deeper understanding of how to convey a believable character that interacts with other characters in a structured, scripted performance.

title: Flute Building
description: After building a Native American flute in Cultural History class, students use it to play a melody they have previously transcribed during a Performing Arts: Music class.

title: Language, Music, Movement, and Song
description: Through language, music, movement, and song, students explore Iroquois rituals and experiment with gestures as a form of expression.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: Students draw upon their Beginnings studies in previous grades, as well as their Cultural History work on the life and beliefs of the Iroquois, to create and perform the dramatization of an Iroquois story before an audience.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: Beginnings is a performance of understanding, a dramatic narrative of the Ross Lower School Cultural History Spiral Curriculum. The performance is timed to coincide with the spring, when the cycle of life begins anew. It is a manifestation of the intellect and imagination—a living work of art, integrating theater, dance, music, Visual Arts, and Cultural History. Through interpretive performance, each grade unfolds and moves its part of the Cultural History story forward, offering a curricular gift to the next grade.

title: Pythagoras and the Monochord
description: In conjunction with their studies of the monochord in Science, each student researches and creates a presentation with a tight focus on one specific aspect of Pythagoras and his contributions.

title: Beginnings Performance
description: Students draw from their Beginnings performances in earlier grades, as well as their integrated instruction in Cultural History and English, to present a culminating performance of understanding.

title: Fortune as a River: Understanding the Many Aspects of Flooding
description: Students complete a series of short experiments determining the porosity of various soil combinations and simulate the effects of a number of variables on flooding events. They apply what they have learned to assessment of the impact sea level rise and flooding may have on their local environment.

title: Raphael’s The School of Athens Presentation
description: As an introduction to the study of the Italian Renaissance, students explore and dissect Raphael’s The School of Athens as an exemplar of Renaissance art and thought.
